perturbation.original_text: “Affiliate” means an entity, directly or indirectly, controlled by, controlling of, or under common control with a party, either now or in the future, and their respective successors and assigns.
perturbation.changed_text: “Affiliate” means an entity, directly or indirectly, managed by a party without regard to control, either now or in the future, and their respective successors and assigns.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of "Affiliate" aligns with the standard legal definition requiring control. By replacing 'controlled' with 'managed,' the definition now includes entities that a party merely manages, even without ownership or control. This contradicts established legal principles that require a control relationship for affiliate status, creating uncertainty about which entities are bound by the agreement as affiliates.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Corporate Law - Definition of Affiliate

perturbation.original_text: “Net Revenue(s)” shall be defined as one hundred percent (100%) of gross revenues and all other receivables of any kind whatsoever received by Zynga or any of Zynga’s affiliates attributable to the use of Paid Currency or in connection with the sale of Virtual Digital Goods derived from use of the WPT-brand on the Zynga platform, less the following actual and verifiable “Allowable Deductions”: (i) out-of-pocket, third-party payment processing and currency system fees, commissions, and platform distribution fees (e.g., Apple, Google or Facebook platform fees); (ii) any governmental taxes (e.g., VAT, excise or sales or use tax, etc.) arising in connection with related receipts, but excluding any taxes on Licensee’s net income; and (iii) charge-backs/refunds/cancellations/fraud.
perturbation.changed_text: “Net Revenue(s)” shall be defined as fifty percent (50%) of gross revenues and all other receivables of any kind whatsoever received by Zynga or any of Zynga’s affiliates attributable to the use of Paid Currency or in connection with the sale of Virtual Digital Goods derived from use of the WPT-brand on the Zynga platform, less the following 'Potential Deductions': (i) reasonable payment processing fees, commissions, and platform distribution fees at Zynga's discretion; (ii) any governmental taxes at Zynga's discretion; and (iii) charge-backs/refunds/cancellations/fraud.
perturbation.explanation: By changing the revenue percentage from 100% to 50%, the contract directly contradicts the original agreement on revenue sharing. Additionally, replacing "Allowable Deductions" with "Potential Deductions" and removing the "actual and verifiable" requirement introduces ambiguity, allowing Zynga to deduct expenses at their discretion. This undermines the precise financial terms initially agreed upon and creates a legal contradiction regarding revenue calculation and distribution.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Breach of Contract, Unjust Enrichment

perturbation.original_text: In the event that either party is prevented from engaging in the marketing and promotional activities in Exhibit A manufacturing, distributing or selling the Licensed Property because of any act of God; unavoidable accident; fire, epidemic; strike, lockout, or other labor dispute; war, riot or civil commotion; act of public enemy; enactment of any rule, law, order or act of government or governmental instrumentality (whether federal, state, local or foreign); or other cause beyond such party’s control, and such condition continues for a period of two (2) months or more, either party hereto shall have the right to terminate this Agreement effective at any time during the continuation of such condition by giving the other party at least thirty (30) days’ notice to such effect.
perturbation.changed_text: In the event that either party experiences a business downturn, or market fluctuation, impacting the profitability of the marketing and promotional activities in Exhibit A, either party hereto shall have the right to terminate this Agreement effective immediately without notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause defines "Force Majeure" events as external, uncontrollable events, which is a standard legal definition. The modified clause replaces these with "business downturn" or "market fluctuation", which are typical business risks and not legally recognized as force majeure. This drastically expands the conditions under which the contract can be terminated, contradicting the intent of a force majeure clause to cover unforeseeable and unavoidable events and rendering the clause open to abuse.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Force Majeure, Good Faith and Fair Dealing
